The DECA programs at Byron P. Steele High School and Samuel Clemens High School each received a check for $5,364.50 at the September 15th monthly luncheon held by The Chamber at the Schertz Civic Center. The proceeds came as a result of the Caterpillar Chamber Bowl fundraiser, held in August at Fiesta Lanes.

Select students from the two high schools were on hand to accept the donation, joined by Dr. Clark Ealy, Superintendent of Schools, and SCUC ISD Board Vice-President Jerry Perkins. Texas State Representative John Kuempel, who generously donated his time and money to the bowling fundraiser, was also present at the luncheon, joining members from area businesses instrumental in raising funds at the August fundraiser. Also present at the luncheon in support was Texas State Senator Donna Campbell.

DECA is the career and technical organization that prepares emerging leaders and entrepreneurs in marketing, finance, hospitality and management at high schools and colleges around the globe.

The SCUC ISD Education Foundation website is also set up to take donations: http://scucisdfoundation.org/donate.

SCUC ISD Education Foundation Mission Statement: The Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City ISD Education Foundation will partner with the community to provide resources to enrich teaching, inspire learning, and maximize innovative opportunities for all students in the Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District.

Sarah Reed has been named the new principal at Rose Garden Elementary School. SCUC ISD Board Trustees approved the recommendation at the regular meeting held on June 16th. Reed has been serving as assistant principal at Schertz Elementary since 2013.

“I am deeply honored and humbled to have the opportunity to join the Rose Garden family,” Reed said upon her hiring. “I believe education is the great equalizer. It provides us with an opportunity to explore unknown paths and unlock our limitless potential.”

She earned her Bachelor’s Degree in Interdisciplinary Studies from Texas State University and immediately embarked on her teaching career at SCUC ISD, beginning at Paschal Elementary School and Sippel Elementary School. Reed was appointed assistant principal at Schertz Elementary shortly after attaining her Master’s of Educational Leadership degree from Texas State. She serves as a Sunday school teacher at her local church. Mrs. Reed is married with two young children.

J. Frank Dobie Jr. High School has acquired Stop the Bleed Kits for every classroom. “I am so excited and proud that we as a team were able to make this happen!” said Dobie School Nurse Marsha Mudge, R.N.

The effort to purchase the 85 Stop the Bleed Kits was a joint effort by Schertz- Cibolo Universal City ISD’s J. Frank Dobie Jr. High School and Schertz EMS. Grants were provided by Wal-Mart. “This is so exciting! It’s such a huge step for us to be prepared if a disaster happens at our campus,” Mudge said.

All Dobie teachers participated in Stop the Bleed training led by Schertz EMS earlier in the school year. They learned how to recognize life-threatening bleeding and intervene effectively.

May 21 is National Stop the Bleed Day: https://bit.ly/3g6nsYE

“Hopefully we will never need to use these kits, but it’s our priority to make Dobie as safe as possible for our students. We are proud of Nurse Mudge for her hard work in acquiring these kits and the support of our community,” said Dobie Jr. High Principal Vernon Simmons.

Isabel Cabrera, seventh grade student at Corbett Junior High, has volunteered her time and efforts during the pandemic shutdown to assist others. She has spent many of her Saturdays to volunteer at the San Antonio Food Bank food drive in downtown San Antonio.

Cabrera has assisted in loading boxes of food for families whose primary source of nourishment comes from donations from the Food Bank. Her mother, Ashley Dailey, in an email sent to Rashad Ray, Corbett principal, credited the leadership examples she receives at the school and other SCUC ISD campuses she has attended in the past. “She is a selfless young woman and would give to someone before thinking of herself,” Dailey wrote in her email. “Thank you for what you do for her and all the students. You are truly great.”

SCUC ISD began its curbside food service this morning for any district student who wants one at Schertz Elementary School while schools are temporarily closed during the Covid-19 pandemic. The meals are provided at no cost.

Child Nutrition Department employees are out to provide breakfast and lunch service. School principal Geri Pope is greeting families as they pick up their meals. Breakfast can be picked up between 7:30 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. Lunch meals can be picked up between 11:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. at the side door by the Schertz Elementary School cafeteria, which is serving as the central location at SCUC ISD.

School IDs are not needed, but the student must be present to receive the meal. The Child Nutrition Department will be able to find student information without an ID.

More information: https://www.scuc.txed.net/Page/32560

A reception to honor former Superintendent Dr. Greg Gibson was held in the board room of the William Malish Building earlier this afternoon. Dr. Gibson retired as Superintendent in January after ten-plus years as leader of the Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District.

District employees, Board Trustees, along with city and county leaders came out to thank Dr. Gibson and his wife, Oteka, for their commitment and service to SCUC ISD.

State Senator Donna Campbell and State Representative John Kuempel were a few of the dignitaries in attendance. Campbell read a resolution thanking Dr. Gibson for his leadership that helped SCUC become, “…one of the fastest-growing districts in the San Antonio-area and in the state.” Meanwhile, Kuempel presented Dr. Gibson another proclamation thanking him for his nearly 30 years as an educator in Texas public education, as well as an American flag.

Contractors working to connect power to the Steele Creek development struck a gas line located in an easement behind Byron P. Steele High School at approximately 11:30 a.m. today. While the winds were blowing away from Steele High School, students in the portable classrooms were moved to the main building, in an abundance of caution. Cibolo Fire Department tested the air in all portable classrooms and ensured that no gas was present.

Gas lines have been shut down, and there is no danger to students and staff at this time. Instruction was not impacted; however, dismissal traffic may be affected this afternoon. Cibolo Police officers will be at Steele HS to assist with the flow of traffic and ensure a safe and smooth dismissal. Crews are working to restore service before the end of the school day.

I can’t wait to see what happens.”
